The spreadsheet on Isadora’s third monitor glowed with the cold, internal logic of a dying star. Each cell in the column labeled ‘Agent Adherence Q3’ was a tiny coffin for sixty seconds of someone else’s life. Red for non-compliance, green for obedience. Her screen was a lush, vibrant forest. Janice, the team lead from the morning shift, was not contributing to the verdancy. She was, at this precise moment, watering the broadloom carpet with what Isadora calculated to be an inefficiently high volume of saline.

“He just… he said he needs space,” Janice hiccupped, her face a crumpled, blotchy mess that clashed terribly with the corporate blue of her cubicle walls. “After five years, Isa. Five. Years.”

Isadora leaned back in her ergonomic chair, the mesh groaning a protest she did not feel. She steepled her fingers, a gesture she’d copied from a senior vice president because it projected thoughtful authority while requiring zero actual thought. She looked at Janice. An asset, currently underperforming. A leak in the plumbing of productivity. The problem wasn’t the boyfriend, the ‘space,’ or the five years. The problem was the moisture on the carpet and the imminent drop in Janice’s team’s call-per-hour metrics.

“Janice,” Isadora said, her voice a flat, placid lake. “The company’s bereavement policy does not extend to romantic disillusionment. You are, however, entitled to one fifteen-minute unscheduled break. I suggest you use it to rehydrate and repair your makeup. The afternoon satellite conference with the Seattle stakeholders is mandatory, and your current aesthetic is, frankly, unprofessional.”

Janice’s mouth fell open, a fresh wave of tears welling up as if summoned by a cruel spell. The sight registered in Isadora’s brain with the same emotional impact as a blinking cursor. It was data. The asset was malfunctioning further. She adjusted her strategy.

“Look,” Isadora sighed, a carefully measured exhalation of manufactured empathy. “What you’re feeling is a significant emotional event. I get it. But compartmentalization is a key skill set in this industry. Use this. Channel the frustration into hitting your targets. Show him, and everyone, that your performance is not contingent on a man’s approval. Make your success the best revenge. It’s what I would do.”

It was a perfect lie. Isadora had never felt the need for revenge because she’d never felt the initial sting of being wronged. She simply identified obstacles and removed them. The lie, however, was a masterstroke of corporate motivational babble. It worked. Janice sniffled, wiped her nose on her sleeve—a disgusting habit—and nodded. The tears slowed. The plumbing was being patched.

“You’re right, Isa. You’re right,” Janice mumbled, pulling herself together with the grim determination of a soldier reassembling her rifle in a trench. “Thank you.”

“Don’t thank me,” Isadora said, turning back to her glowing screens. “Update the Q3 projections by noon.”

She clicked open a hidden window on her primary monitor, a window that had nothing to do with Agent Adherence or stakeholder synergies. It was a far more important spreadsheet, one she had been building for six months. The title was simple: ‘The Project.’ Column A listed her current monthly salary, her benefits package quantified in pesos, her projected 1.5% annual raise. Column B listed the cost of living in Baguio—rent, utilities, the absurd price of good cheese at the city market. Column C was the variable, the source of all her calculations. It was titled ‘Alternate Revenue Streams.’ It was mostly empty, a desert of possibility, save for a few entries detailing small, private winnings from weekend games at the Camp John Hay Golf Club.

Outside her office window, the city of Baguio was disappearing. A thick, white fog, born from the damp pines and the cool mountain air, was rolling up from the valley, swallowing the colorful chaos of the hillside houses until only the closest, most stubborn structures remained visible. It was like the world was being erased. Isadora felt a kinship with the fog. It was clean, cold, and beautifully indifferent. It hid the mess. Her job, she decided, as she looked from the fog to the weeping team lead now furiously typing in her cubicle, was the mess. A well-paying, prestigious, soul-shreddingly tedious mess.

For two years, she had been the perfect BPO Senior Operations Manager. She moved human pieces around a board, optimized their functions, and presented the results in elegant PowerPoint decks. She was good at it precisely because she felt nothing for the pieces. They were numbers, outputs, resources. But the game was becoming tiresome. The rewards, static. The spreadsheet, ‘The Project,’ was her escape hatch. The math, however, was not yet in her favor. The risk of failure was 67.4%. Unacceptable.

She spent another hour dissecting data streams, her mind a scalpel cutting through the fat of corporate jargon to the lean muscle of pure profit. Then, during a lull, she looked out the window again. The fog had thinned, and a sliver of weak, afternoon sun illuminated the distant, green fairway of the golf course, a slash of impossible emerald amidst the grey concrete and rusting rooftops. It called to her. Not with sentiment, but with the crisp logic of a perfect equation. On the golf course, the rules were clear. The physics was absolute. The swing was a matter of mechanics, not morale. You hit the ball, it went where your skill dictated. There were no weeping team leads, no pointless meetings, no motivational posters about teamwork. There was only the club, the ball, and the hole. Cause and effect in its purest form.

A new number popped into her head. A new variable. Not a financial one, but something more potent. She created a new column in her spreadsheet: ‘Daily Misery Index.’ She assigned it a numeric value of 8.5 out of a possible 10. She then factored this into her risk calculation. When you quantified dissatisfaction, the appeal of a high-risk, high-reward scenario increased exponentially. The risk of failure for ‘The Project’ dropped to 48.2%. Still high. But it was, for the first time, less than a coin toss.

She closed the secret spreadsheet, stood up, and walked out of her office. She strode past Janice’s cubicle without a glance and went directly to her Director’s door. She didn’t knock.

The drive home was a descent into the beautiful, maddening anarchy she secretly adored. Her small sedan navigated the clogged artery of Session Road, a chaotic ballet of smoke-belching jeepneys, oblivious pedestrians, and taxis that stopped with suicidal abruptness. The air, thick with the smell of diesel and roasting peanuts, was cold enough to warrant the leather jacket she wore. Other people complained about the traffic, the noise, the sheer crush of humanity. Isadora found it stimulating. It was a system in constant flux, a thousand independent variables all colliding at once. To navigate it successfully was a victory.

Her mother’s house was a relic from another time. An old, two-story wooden structure in the quiet, pine-shrouded neighborhood of Outlook Drive. It was a house that smelled of lemon floor wax, old wood, and her mother’s ever-present gardenia perfume. It was a house of memories, a concept Isadora understood academically but did not experience.

Elena Silang was in the garden, tending to her prize-winning orchids. She was a small, bird-like woman whose entire life was a performance for an unseen audience of neighbors and relatives. Her face, a mask of carefully managed concern, turned to Isadora as she crunched up the gravel path.

“Isadora, anak. You’re home early,” Elena said, wiping her hands on her apron. Her eyes did a swift, expert appraisal of Isadora’s attire, her posture, her expression. “Is something wrong? You didn’t get fired, did you? Tita Remy’s son just got promoted, you know. To regional manager.”

“I wasn’t fired, Ma,” Isadora said, stopping before her mother. She didn’t help with the orchids. She never did. “I resigned.”

The gardening shears fell from Elena’s hand, clattering on the flagstones. “You what? Resigned? Isadora, are you insane? That job is the best thing that ever happened to you! The benefits! The prestige! What will people say?”

“I have no idea,” Isadora replied, unconcerned. “I imagine Tita Remy will be thrilled.”

“This isn’t a joke! You can’t just quit a job like that! What are you going to do? Your father, God rest his soul, would be so disappointed.”

This was a predictable move in their conversational chess match. The Invocation of the Sainted Father. Isadora was unfazed. “Father would be disappointed that I stayed in a position with a Daily Misery Index of 8.5 for so long. He valued efficiency.”

“Daily Misery what?” Elena’s face was a knot of confusion and horror. “You’re not making any sense. You need a stable job. A husband. Grandchildren. Not… whatever this is. This madness.”

“I have a plan, Ma,” Isadora said. It was not a reassurance. It was a statement of fact. “I’m going to play golf.”

“Golf?” Elena almost shrieked the word. “That’s a hobby for rich old men! It’s not a job! You will end up broke and alone, and I’ll have to tell everyone my daughter threw her life away to chase a stupid white ball around a field.”

“The balls are of premium quality, actually. And the field is a meticulously maintained landscape of bentgrass and tifdwarf,” Isadora corrected. “My financial projections are still in the beta phase, but the potential upside is significant.”

Her mother just stared at her, her face pale. She looked, Isadora thought, like one of the koi in the small pond by the patio, mouth open, gills fluttering, utterly bewildered by the world outside the water. The conversation was over. The asset, in this case her mother, was not convinced, but her approval was not a necessary component for the project’s initiation.

Isadora left her sputtering in the garden and went to her room. She changed into her golf attire. The crisp polo shirt, the tailored slacks, the spiked shoes. It felt like putting on a uniform for a war she actually wanted to fight. She grabbed her clubs and left, the slam of the old screen door punctuating her mother’s final, desperate plea.

The air at Camp John Hay was different. Cleaner. Sharper. The scent of pine was so thick you could almost taste it. Here, on the rolling hills of the course, the chaos of the city felt a world away. This was her sanctuary. Her laboratory.

She stood at the first tee box, the fairway unfolding before her like a promise. This was where the math became real. The wind speed, the humidity, the lie of the ball, the subtle slope of the ground—all data points to be processed into a single, fluid motion. Her practice swings cut through the air with a soft, predatory hiss.

She needed to be here. She needed to recalibrate her senses after the sterile environment of the office and the emotional clutter of her mother’s house. But something was wrong. Her usual caddy, the one man in Baguio who understood the intricate mechanics of her game and her mind, was not waiting for her at the clubhouse. Mang Berto, a wiry old man with a face like a topographical map of the Cordillera mountains, was as essential to her game as her nine-iron. He wasn’t just a bag carrier; he was a silent consultant, a human wind vane, a repository of course knowledge that bordered on the supernatural.

She asked after him at the front desk. The young woman there gave her a look of practiced sympathy. “Ah, Ma’am Isa. Mang Berto. He was admitted to the hospital last night. His son called this morning.”

Isadora felt a cold, hard knot form in her stomach. It was not concern. It was not empathy. It was the icy grip of logistical frustration. A critical piece of her new enterprise, the very foundation of ‘The Project,’ had just been rendered unavailable.

“What’s wrong with him?” she asked, her tone sharp.

The girl flinched. “They… they said it’s the Big C, ma’am. Pancreatic. Stage four.”

Isadora stood there, her golf glove halfway on. Stage four. The prognosis was statistically dire. The probability of Mang Berto returning to the course in a functional capacity was… negligible. Her spreadsheet, her beautiful plan, her 48.2% chance of success, had just taken a catastrophic hit. The numbers were spinning in her head, recalculating, the red cells of failure multiplying like a virus.

She looked out at the first green, a perfect circle of manicured perfection under the late afternoon sun. A group of loud businessmen in pastel shirts were laughing as one of them missed a simple putt. They were amateurs. Tourists. They were playing a game. For Isadora, it was never a game. And she had just lost her most valuable piece before the match had even begun. The Baguio fog, which had seemed so clean and beautiful an hour ago, now began to roll back in, not as an eraser, but as a shroud.

For a full twelve seconds, Isadora did not move. Her mind, a precision instrument honed for optimization, was frantically re-running every calculation for ‘The Project.’ Mang Berto was not a friend; he was a proprietary tool, a unique piece of hardware calibrated perfectly to her system. His knowledge of the course’s subtle moods, the way a morning rain would affect the roll on the seventh green by 3 PM, the exact gust of wind that funneled through the pines at the notoriously difficult twelfth hole—these were not anecdotes, they were terabytes of irreplaceable data. His illness was not a tragedy; it was a critical system error, a complete corruption of her primary operational dataset. Pancreatic. Stage four. The words were medically precise and statistically hopeless. A terminal diagnosis. The asset was a total loss.

“Which hospital?” she asked, her voice devoid of any inflection. The receptionist, startled by the abrupt question after the long silence, fumbled with a piece of paper on her desk.
“Baguio General, ma’am. He’s in the charity ward.”

The charity ward. Another data point. A grim one. It implied a lack of resources, which in turn implied a rapid, unmitigated decline. The likelihood of finding a solution there was infinitesimally small. The risk of failure for ‘The Project’ had just surged past 80%. It was no longer a calculated risk; it was fiscal suicide. The logical move was to abort, to return to the soul-crushing stability of her former job, hat in hand, and recalibrate her misery index for another five years. But the thought of her office, of Janice, of the meaningless PowerPoints, was more nauseating than any statistical failure.

“I’ll take another caddy,” Isadora stated, pulling her glove on with a sharp snap of elastic. She would not abort. She would run a diagnostic. She needed to establish a new baseline, to quantify the exact deficit created by Mang Berto’s absence. She needed to know precisely how screwed she was.

The replacement caddy was a young man named Dennis, barely out of his teens, with a nervous energy that vibrated off him in palpable waves. He kept trying to make small talk, complimenting her form, asking about her day, his chatter a constant, irritating static in her concentration. On the second hole, a long par-four with a dogleg right, she asked for his read on the wind. He licked a finger and held it up, a gesture of such folksy incompetence that Isadora felt a surge of pure, cold rage. Mang Berto would have known from the tremble of a specific leaf on a specific acacia tree sixty yards away. Dennis suggested a seven-iron. Isadora’s own calculations screamed for a six. She took the seven-iron just to confirm his uselessness. The ball fell short, catching the lip of the bunker. The data was conclusive: the standard-issue caddy was a net liability.

She played five more holes, each shot a fresh exercise in frustration. Her swing, usually a seamless extension of her will, felt clumsy and disconnected. The beautiful, clear logic of the course was gone, replaced by the guesswork of a novice. Dennis was a constant distraction, a human pop-up ad in her field of vision. He represented the average, the mean, the very thing she had built her life around excelling beyond. The game was no longer a matter of physics; it was a negotiation with incompetence. After shanking a simple chip on the seventh green, she stopped. The sun was beginning to dip behind the mountains, casting long, funereal shadows across the fairway. This was a waste of daylight.

“We’re done,” she announced, pulling the flag from the hole herself. Dennis looked confused.
“But ma’am, we still have eleven holes…”
“The test is complete. The results are inadequate,” she said, striding back toward the clubhouse without waiting for him to gather the clubs. She left him standing on the green, a bewildered monument to mediocrity. She didn’t care. He was a flawed data point, and she was discarding him.

In the car, she didn’t drive back to the empty, accusing quiet of her mother’s house. The meticulously structured world of ‘The Project’ had collapsed. Her calculations were useless, her projections a fantasy. But Isadora was not a person who accepted failure. She was a person who re-evaluated variables and changed the parameters of the problem. Mang Berto was the problem. His sudden, inconvenient mortality was the bug in her code. And so, guided by a grim and unfamiliar logic, she found herself driving towards the one place in the city she instinctively loathed: Baguio General Hospital.

The hospital was everything her golf course was not: chaotic, loud, and saturated with the cloying smells of antiseptic and desperation. The lobby was a frantic ecosystem of crying relatives, overworked nurses, and the quiet, shuffling despair of the sick. It was the physical manifestation of every messy, unquantifiable human emotion she had spent her life avoiding. Her golf shoes, with their soft spikes, made an unnerving, clicking sound on the worn linoleum floors, each step announcing her as an intruder, a creature from a different, more orderly world. She ignored the stares, her face a mask of cold purpose. She was not here to offer condolences. She was not here to comfort a sick old man. She was here to assess the damage to her investment and to determine if any part of it, any derivative asset, could be salvaged from the wreckage.

The charity ward was a long, cavernous room that smelled of boiled cabbage and slow decay. It was a production line of human suffering, organized with a grim, underfunded efficiency that offended Isadora on a purely professional level. Beds were lined up in two rows against the walls, separated by flimsy curtains that offered the illusion of privacy but failed to contain the symphony of coughs, moans, and whispered prayers. Fluorescent lights hummed overhead, casting a sickly, greenish pallor on everything, making the living look nearly as gaunt as the dying. It was a system operating at a catastrophic loss, leaking life at every seam. Isadora navigated the narrow aisle between the beds, her gaze sweeping over the occupants with the dispassionate air of a factory inspector searching for a specific, broken machine.

She found him in a bed near the far end of the ward, by a grimy window that looked out onto a brick wall. The man in the bed was a shrunken, yellowed effigy of the caddy she knew. The wiry strength was gone, replaced by a brittle frailty. His skin, once the color of rich earth, was now a pale, waxy parchment stretched thin over his bones. An IV tube snaked from a bag of clear liquid into his arm, a pathetic, translucent lifeline. Mang Berto was no longer a repository of data; he was a corrupted file, minutes away from permanent deletion. Standing beside the bed, his back to her, was a young man in a worn t-shirt and jeans, his shoulders slumped in a posture of weary vigilance.

“I am looking for Berto Silvan,” Isadora stated, her voice cutting cleanly through the ambient noise of the ward. She did not lower it. It was a statement, not a request. The young man turned, startled. He had his father’s eyes, but they were clouded with a mixture of exhaustion and suspicion. He looked at Isadora’s expensive leather jacket, her pristine slacks, her aura of crisp, unassailable wealth, and his expression hardened.
“Who’s asking?” he said, his voice low and defensive, deliberately positioning himself between her and the bed.

“My name is Isadora Silang. I employ your father at the Camp John Hay Golf Club,” she said, as if presenting credentials. The word ‘employ’ hung in the air, a stark reminder of the power dynamic. She was the client, the patron, the one who paid for services rendered. The young man’s jaw tightened.

“His name is Leo,” he said, a sharp edge to his tone. “And he’s not employed by anyone right now. He’s sick.”
From the bed, a weak, rasping sound emerged. “Leo… anak… let her be.” Mang Berto’s eyes had fluttered open. They were sunken, but they were lucid. He recognized her. “Ma’am Isa,” he breathed, the words barely a whisper. “You came.” There was a flicker of something in his gaze—surprise, maybe even a faint, misplaced touch of honor that his most demanding client would seek him out here. Isadora registered it as simple acknowledgement of her presence.

“Yes,” she confirmed, stepping around the still-bristling Leo to get a clearer view of the asset. “I was informed of your condition. Stage four pancreatic cancer. A terminal diagnosis with a median survival time of three to six months, depending on the efficacy of palliative treatments which, given this facility, are likely substandard.” She delivered the prognosis with the detached clarity of a newsreader announcing stock market figures. Leo flinched as if she had physically struck him, a sharp intake of breath hissing between his teeth. Mang Berto, however, just held her gaze, a flicker of what looked like grim understanding in his eyes.

“I require a replacement,” Isadora continued, seeing no value in prolonging the preamble. “Your knowledge of the course is specific and not easily replicated. I need to know if you have documented your methodologies. Charts, notes, anything of that nature. Or, failing that, if you have trained a successor. Someone who understands the wind patterns at the fifteenth hole, the morning dew’s effect on the east-facing greens. A protege.”

Silence. A profound, stunned silence descended on their small section of the ward, a vacuum that even the surrounding moans and coughs could not penetrate. Leo stared at her, his face a mask of utter disbelief, his mouth slightly agape. He looked from Isadora’s impassive face to his dying father and back again, as if trying to process a language from another dimension. When he finally spoke, his voice was a strangled whisper of pure, unadulterated rage.

“Get out,” he said, his whole body trembling. “Get. Out. Now.”

“Your emotional response is unproductive,” Isadora stated calmly, treating his fury as a minor system glitch. “I am not here to cause distress. I am here to solve a logistical problem. Your father’s sudden unavailability has jeopardized a significant personal project. His expertise is a valuable commodity. I am willing to compensate him, or his family, for the successful transfer of that commodity.” She reached into her jacket, as if to produce a wallet, the gesture a clear indication that she believed this entire messy human tragedy could be reduced to a simple, clean financial transaction.

That was the final straw. “Commodity?” Leo exploded, his voice cracking. “He’s my father! He’s a man! Not a… a thing for you to use! He’s lying here, dying, and you’re talking about your golf game?” He took a step towards her, his hands clenched into white-knuckled fists. “You have no heart. No soul. You are the sickest person in this room.”

“Leo,” Mang Berto’s voice was surprisingly firm, cutting through his son’s anger. It was a weak sound, but it carried the familiar weight of paternal authority. Leo stopped, turning back to the bed, his chest heaving. The old man’s eyes were fixed on Isadora, and for the first time, she saw a new variable in them. It wasn’t deference or fear. It was… pity. He was pitying *her*. The thought was so alien, so computationally absurd, that her mind momentarily stalled.

“Ma’am Isa,” Mang Berto rasped, beckoning her closer with a slight curl of his fingers. “There are no… notes.” He took a shallow, painful breath. “This is not a thing you write down. It is a thing you feel. In the bones. In the air.” He paused, gathering his strength. “My son… Leo… he does not have the knack. He is a good boy. A carpenter. His hands are for wood, not for the wind.” Another pause. “But… my brother’s boy. My nephew. Rafael. He used to follow me. When he was young. He has the eyes for it.”

A new data point. A potential lead. Rafael. Isadora’s internal systems immediately began processing this new information, her mind already moving on from the dying man in the bed to the problem of locating and assessing this ‘Rafael.’ The emotional outburst from Leo was already being archived as irrelevant, discarded data.

“Where can I find him?” she asked, her focus absolute.

Mang Berto gave a weak, wheezing cough that might have been a laugh. “He is… not like me, Ma’am Isa. He is a wild one. You will find him where the trouble is. Try the cockpit. The one in Irisan. He wastes his money there, on the fighting cocks.”

The cockpit. A gambling den for cockfighting. Another chaotic, unpredictable human system. Isadora filed the information away. A new location. A new variable. A new name. The visit had yielded a tangible result. The mission was a success.

“Thank you, Berto,” she said. It was the first time she had ever used his first name. She turned and walked away without another word, her golf shoes clicking on the linoleum, a steady, rhythmic sound that receded down the long ward. She did not look back at the son who was now openly weeping, nor at the old man who had just given her the last useful piece of himself. She was already calculating the probability of this new lead, Rafael, being a viable asset. The Daily Misery Index of the hospital faded behind her as she stepped out into the cool evening air, her mind once again clean, cold, and beautifully, brutally, focused on the math.

Chapter 2

The cockpit in Irisan was not a building; it was a wound in the hillside, festering under a corrugated tin roof. The drive there had been a journey through descending levels of civic order, the paved roads of the city center giving way to rutted dirt tracks barely wide enough for her sedan. The air here lost the clean scent of pine and took on the thick, organic smells of pigsties, damp earth, and woodsmoke. Isadora parked on a muddy verge between two battered Tamaraw FX taxis, their drivers eyeing her sleek car with a mixture of curiosity and predatory appraisal. She ignored them, her focus already on the low, sprawling structure ahead, from which a dull roar emanated, a sound like a single, multi-throated beast in the throes of some primal passion.

Stepping inside was like plunging into a different state of matter. The air was a hot, humid soup, thick with the stench of cheap gin, unwashed bodies, and the sharp, coppery tang of blood. A dense haze of cigarette smoke hung in the air, catching the weak light from bare bulbs in shifting, ghostly curtains. At the center of it all was the pit, a circle of packed dirt enclosed by a low wooden wall. Tiers of rough-hewn bleachers rose up around it, packed with a frantic, shouting mass of men. It was a purely masculine space, raw and adrenalized. Her presence, in her tailored slacks and expensive jacket, was a profound anomaly. The wave of noise momentarily faltered as heads turned, the shouting dropping to a low buzz of whispers and speculative glances. Isadora registered the attention as she would a change in ambient temperature—a data point, but not one that required a reaction.

She did not look for a seat. She stood near the entrance, her back to a rough wooden pillar, and began to observe the system. It was chaos, but it was a structured chaos. Money, in crumpled, dirty bills, was being exchanged with a rapid-fire series of shouts and arcane hand signals. Bets were being called, odds screamed, loyalties sworn and betrayed in the space of seconds. In the pit, two handlers were holding their roosters, magnificent, terrifying birds with iridescent feathers and eyes like polished obsidian. Steel spurs, three-inch razors known as ‘tari,’ were strapped to their left legs. The referee gave a signal, and the birds were released. The roar of the crowd became a deafening, unified wall of sound. Isadora did not watch the fight, the brutal, chaotic blur of feathers and steel. She watched the faces in the crowd. She was looking for a specific type of signal amidst the noise.

She scanned the tiers, her gaze sweeping past faces contorted with greed, hope, and animalistic excitement. She was looking for the telltale features her mind had cataloged from Mang Berto’s face, cross-referenced with his description: a wild one. Her eyes settled on a young man in the third row. He had Mang Berto’s high cheekbones and deep-set eyes, but where the old man’s face was a study in placid wisdom, this one was a canvas of restless, volatile energy. He was leaning forward, knuckles white on the railing, his entire body coiled like a spring. He screamed encouragement at one of the birds, his voice raw with desperate investment. He looked nothing like a carpenter. He looked like a nerve ending, exposed and firing.

The fight was over in less than a minute. A flurry of motion, a final, piteous squawk, and one of the birds lay still on the dirt floor, a splash of crimson staining its magnificent plumage. A collective groan went through one half of the crowd, an explosive cheer from the other. The young man Isadora had been watching slammed his fist on the railing, a single, violent motion of utter defeat. He sagged back, his face ashen, the manic energy draining out of him to be replaced by a hollow, vacant despair. She saw another man clap him on the shoulder, a gesture that was half-commiseration, half-demand for payment. The young man dug into his pocket and came out with a pathetic, crumpled wad of bills, which he handed over with a look of profound self-loathing. The variable had been located. Its current state had been assessed: vulnerable.

Isadora began to move. She ascended the rough bleachers with a sure-footedness that seemed out of place, her path cutting through the throng of men who parted before her as if she were a ghost. She stopped directly behind the young man, who was now staring blankly at the blood-soaked dirt of the pit.
“Rafael,” she said. Her voice was not loud, but it was perfectly pitched to cut through the din. It was a command, not a question.
He started, spinning around to face her. His eyes, so like his uncle’s, widened in confusion as they took in her appearance. “Do I know you?” he asked, his tone laced with suspicion and the residual aggression of a losing gambler.

“You do not,” Isadora replied. “Your uncle, Berto Silvan, is in the charity ward at Baguio General. He has Stage Four pancreatic cancer. He suggested I find you here.” She delivered the information like a series of hammer blows, each fact stripped of any emotional buffer. She saw the news of his uncle’s condition register, a flicker of genuine shock and pain crossing his face before it was quickly shuttered behind a mask of defensive hostility.

“What’s it to you?” he snarled. “You some kind of debt collector for the hospital?”
“I was his client. I play golf,” Isadora stated. “He was my caddy. His knowledge was a unique and valuable asset. An asset which is now lost. He claimed you have ‘the eyes for it.’ I am here to verify that claim and, if it proves true, to offer you his position.”

Rafael stared at her, then threw his head back and let out a short, bark-like laugh devoid of any humor. “You’re kidding me. The old man is dying, and he sends a rich golfer to hire me to carry her sticks? You’ve got to be kidding me.” He turned his back on her, a clear dismissal. “I’m not a servant, lady. Find someone else to follow you around the pretty grass.”

“I am not offering you a job as a servant,” Isadora said, her voice remaining perfectly level. “I am offering you a business proposition. Your uncle’s expertise, if you possess a fraction of it, is worth a considerable amount of money. Far more than you are capable of winning in this statistically unfavorable environment.” She gestured dismissively at the pit, where attendants were already sweeping away the feathers and blood to prepare for the next match. “I am prepared to pay a retainer, against future earnings, that would more than cover the losses you just incurred, and any other outstanding debts you may have.”

That made him turn back. The mention of money, of his specific, immediate lack of it, had breached his wall of pride. He looked at her with narrowed, assessing eyes. The desperation she had seen from afar was now visible up close, a frantic, hunted look behind the bravado. He was calculating, but not like she did. He was weighing his wounded pride against his empty pockets.

“What makes you think I know anything about golf?” he challenged, though the fire in his voice had been dampened.
“Your uncle seemed to believe so. It is a testable hypothesis,” Isadora said. “I propose a trial. One round. Eighteen holes. You will act as my caddy. I will pay you five thousand pesos for your time, regardless of the outcome. If your input provides a measurable improvement to my performance against my established baseline, we will discuss a more permanent, and more lucrative, arrangement. If it does not, we part ways. You will be five thousand pesos richer. I will have the data I require.”

It was a perfect proposal, a clean, logical construction that appealed directly to his immediate needs while establishing her own dominance in the negotiation. She was not asking him to be a caddy; she was challenging him, daring him to prove his worth. She was quantifying his "knack" in the only language he seemed to truly understand: a cash offer with no strings attached. She could see the gears turning in his head, the struggle between his ingrained defiance and the undeniable allure of the money. He looked from her cold, impassive face to the blood-stained pit, then back again. The choice was between the chaotic, uncertain violence of this world, and the clean, cold logic of hers.

Chapter 3

A long moment stretched between them, a pocket of silence in the roaring chaos of the cockpit. Rafael’s eyes flickered from Isadora’s unblinking gaze to the wad of cash in a nearby winner’s hand, then back. Five thousand pesos was a fortune in this context. It was more than he’d lost tonight; it was a reset button on a week’s worth of bad decisions. His pride was a raw, throbbing thing, but pride didn’t pay rent, and it certainly couldn’t help his uncle. The woman was arrogant, cold, and talking about his dying Tiyo Berto like he was a broken piece of machinery, but the money she offered was real. He gave one last, disgusted look at the bloody dirt of the pit.

“Fine,” he spat, the word tasting like defeat. “One round. But if you think I’m calling you ‘ma’am,’ you’re crazy.” He thrust out his chin, a last stand of defiance.

“Your form of address is an irrelevant variable,” Isadora replied, her expression unchanged. “The clubhouse at Camp John Hay. Tomorrow. 6 AM. Do not be late.” She turned and walked away without waiting for a confirmation, her straight back and purposeful stride a stark line of order cutting through the swirling mess of the crowd. Rafael watched her go, a strange mix of resentment and grudging admiration churning in his gut. He had a feeling he had just made a deal with something not entirely human.

The next morning, the air at Camp John Hay was cold, clean, and achingly pure. Mist clung to the hollows of the fairways, and the rising sun painted the tops of the pine trees in hues of gold and rose. It was a world of serene, calculated beauty, a universe away from the smoky hell of the Irisan cockpit. Isadora was already on the practice green, her movements precise and economical, as she rolled a series of ten-foot putts. She wore the same focused, impassive expression she wore in the office, her mind already deep inside the game. Rafael arrived at 6:05 AM, walking with a sullen slouch. He wore the same jeans from the night before, now stained with a bit of mud, and a faded band t-shirt. He looked like a trespasser, a piece of urban grit marring a pristine landscape.

Isadora watched him approach, her putting stroke never faltering. “You are five minutes late,” she stated. “Punctuality is a prerequisite for efficiency.” She gestured with her chin towards a small locker. “There is a staff polo shirt and a pair of trousers in there. Change. My brand requires a certain aesthetic. You are a reflection of that brand for the next four hours.”

Rafael bristled, his mouth opening to spit back a retort, but he stopped. He looked at his own reflection in the clubhouse window, then at the other golfers and caddies beginning to mill about, all in their crisp, clean uniforms. He was an anomaly. A problem. He hated her for it, but he also understood the cold logic. Without a word, he grabbed the clothes and disappeared into the locker room. When he emerged, the neatly pressed khaki and collared shirt looked like a costume on him, but he no longer stood out. He had been assimilated. Isadora nodded once, a gesture of minimal approval. “The bag,” she said, and began walking towards the first tee box.

For the first four holes, she played in near-complete silence, a machine executing its programming. She surveyed each shot, took practice swings, selected her own club, and hit. Rafael simply walked beside her, carrying the heavy bag, his role reduced to that of a beast of burden. He said nothing, his face a sullen mask of boredom. He watched her process, the way she used a laser rangefinder to get the exact distance, the way she consulted a small notebook before every shot. It was like watching someone do advanced mathematics, not play a game. On the fifth hole, a long par-three over a small ravine, a tricky, swirling wind began to pick up, rustling the tops of the pines.

Isadora went through her routine. Rangefinder: 167 yards. Notebook: uphill lie, morning wind from the east usually adds ten yards. Her calculation was a firm five-iron. She pulled the club from the bag, took her stance, and was about to begin her backswing when Rafael spoke for the first time.
“That’s the wrong club,” he said, his voice flat.

Isadora froze, her concentration broken. She slowly straightened up and turned to look at him. It was the same impertinent defiance from the cockpit. “My calculations are precise,” she said, her voice dangerously quiet.

“I don’t care about your calculations,” Rafael shot back, gesturing with his head toward the ravine. “Look at the ferns down there, near the water. They aren’t moving. Now look at the top of that big tree on the right. The leaves are blowing the other way. The wind is swirling. It’s a wall in front of you, but it’s going to help you on the right side. You hit that five-iron straight, the wind will knock it into the ravine. You have to aim for the right-side bunker and let the wind bring it back. Use a six-iron. A soft six.”

His words were not technical. They were a story, a description of unseen forces. It was nonsense. It was intuition and folklore, the very opposite of her data-driven worldview. Her mind screamed to dismiss it, to trust her numbers, to put this insolent boy in his place. But then she remembered the purpose of the experiment. *A testable hypothesis.* She had to know. The risk of one bad hole was acceptable to acquire the necessary data. With a flicker of something she would never admit was uncertainty, she put the five-iron back in the bag and held out her hand. “Six-iron,” she commanded.

Rafael handed it to her, a small, knowing smirk playing on his lips. Isadora’s jaw tightened. She hated that smirk. She hated this entire unscientific process. She lined up her shot exactly as he’d said, aiming at the sand trap, a target that felt ludicrously wrong. Her swing was perfect, a smooth application of force. The ball launched into the air, heading directly for the bunker. For a second, she felt a surge of vindication—he was wrong. Then, as if hitting an invisible wall of glass, the ball stalled, its trajectory bending sharply to the left. It dropped from the sky, landing softly on the green not eight feet from the pin. It was a perfect shot. A shot her own meticulous calculations would have sent into the ravine.

She stood there for a moment, motionless, processing the result. It was impossible. An outcome based on "the feeling of the wind" and "the story of the leaves" had proven superior to hard data. It was like watching a shaman’s chant cure a computer virus. The cognitive dissonance was deeply unsettling. She looked over at Rafael. The smirk was gone, replaced by a quiet, confident calm. He was just looking at the green, as if the outcome had never been in doubt.

The dynamic of the game changed instantly. On the next hole, Isadora paused before selecting her club. “The read?” she asked, the two words costing her a significant amount of pride.
Rafael didn't answer immediately. He sniffed the air, his gaze distant, scanning the entire landscape. “It’s getting warmer. The ground is firming up. The ball will roll out more than you think. Take one less club and play for the bounce.”
She did. And again, he was right. Hole after hole, his advice was uncanny. He didn’t use a rangefinder; he seemed to know the distances by instinct. He didn’t consult a notebook; he read the texture of the grass, the angle of the sun, the mood of the wind. He spoke about the course as if it were a living thing, with habits and secrets. He was not a caddy; he was an interpreter, translating the course’s silent language for her. For the first time, Isadora felt her own rigid system of logic was not the master key, but merely one limited tool.

By the eighteenth hole, Isadora was playing with a fluidity she hadn’t felt in years. Freed from the constant, grinding calculations, her mind was quieter, her swing more instinctive. She was still in control, but it was a different kind of control—a partnership with the environment rather than a battle against it. Rafael’s presence, initially an irritant, had become a seamless part of her process. They finished the round. She had shot a 71, two under par. It was her best score on this course in over a year. The data was irrefutable. The hypothesis was confirmed.

She stood by her car in the parking lot as the morning sun grew warmer. Rafael was standing awkwardly a few feet away, waiting for his payment. Isadora pulled a crisp five-thousand-peso bill from her wallet and handed it to him. He took it, his eyes fixed on the money.
“The trial period is over,” Isadora said, her voice flat and decisive. “Your performance was satisfactory. The asset is viable.”
Rafael looked up from the bill, a wary expression on his face. “So that’s it? We’re done?”
“No,” Isadora replied, opening her car door. “Phase one is complete. Phase two is the project itself. I intend to enter the Philippine Ladies Open qualifying tournament in three months. I intend to win. Your compensation will be a ten percent share of all winnings, in addition to a monthly salary that is double what your uncle earned. The work will be exclusive. You will caddy for no one else. We begin training tomorrow. 6 AM. Sharp.” She got into her car and shut the door, leaving him standing there with five thousand pesos in his hand and an offer that was as insane, and as impossible to refuse, as the woman who had made it.

Rafael stood alone in the vast, empty parking lot, the five-thousand-peso bill a warm, crisp reality in his hand. The sun was climbing higher, burning away the last of the morning mist, and the quiet opulence of the country club felt like a foreign country he had been granted a temporary, bewildering visa for. Isadora’s sedan was gone, leaving only the faint smell of exhaust and a silence that hummed with the impossible proposition she had left in her wake. Ten percent of winnings. A salary. Exclusive work. She hadn’t been offering him a job; she had been drafting him into a war he didn’t know was being fought. He looked at the money, then in the direction of the city, and a grim resolve settled over him. He knew exactly where this money needed to go.

He did not go back to his cramped boarding house room. He caught a series of jeepneys, the crisp golf uniform he was still wearing earning him curious and resentful stares, and made his way back to the chaotic, human mess of Baguio General Hospital. He walked into the charity ward with a confidence he hadn’t possessed the day before. The smell of antiseptic and suffering was the same, but he was different. He was no longer just the desperate nephew; he was a man with a purpose, with capital. He found his cousin Leo sitting by Mang Berto’s bed, spooning a thin, watery broth into the old man’s mouth.

Without a word, Rafael peeled off four of the thousand-peso bills and pressed them into Leo’s hand. Leo stared at the money, then at Rafael’s strange clothes, his face a mixture of shock and suspicion. “Where did you get this?” he demanded, his voice a low whisper.
“I earned it,” Rafael said, his gaze fixed on his uncle. Mang Berto’s eyes were open, and they were watching him. There was a faint, questioning light in their depths. “I caddied for that woman. The one from yesterday.”

“She paid you this much? For one round?” Leo’s disbelief was palpable.
Rafael ignored him and pulled a stool closer to the bed. “Tiyo,” he said softly. “She shot a 71. Two under.”
A slow smile, cracked and weak, spread across Mang Berto’s face. It was the most life Rafael had seen in him for days. The old man’s hand, frail and papery, crept across the thin blanket and weakly gripped Rafael’s arm. “The eyes,” Mang Berto rasped, his voice a dry rustle of leaves. “You have the eyes.”

“She wants me to work for her, Tiyo. All the time. Leading up to a big tournament,” Rafael confessed, the words tumbling out. “She offered me a salary. A percentage. It’s crazy money.” He looked at his uncle, searching for guidance. “She’s… not right in the head. She talks about people like they’re machine parts. She tried to buy your brain yesterday.”
Mang Berto’s grip tightened slightly. “She is not a person,” he whispered, and Rafael had to lean in to hear. “She is a puzzle. A very difficult one. Do not try to solve her. Just solve the course for her. The rest is just noise.” He coughed, a painful, rattling sound. “Take the job, anak. It is a cleaner game than the one you play with the chickens.”

Meanwhile, Isadora was back in her own version of a laboratory: her childhood bedroom, now stripped of all personal effects and converted into a sterile command center. The only warmth came from the glow of her three monitors. She had already showered, changing out of her golf attire and into a simple, severe black turtleneck. On the center screen, ‘The Project’ was open. With a series of brisk, decisive clicks, she began her updates.
The ‘Daily Misery Index’ column was deleted without ceremony. In its place, she created a new, complex series of interconnected cells. ‘Asset: Rafael (Volatile Human Element).’ She couldn’t quantify his skills in any traditional metric. ‘Knack’ and ‘eyes for it’ were useless, unscientific terms. She could, however, quantify his impact. She created a new metric: ‘Performance Multiplier.’ Based on the day’s round, she assigned it an initial value of 1.4, representing a 40% potential improvement over her baseline. She then factored in a ‘Volatility Index’ of 90%, acknowledging that his performance was tied to mood, pride, and other dangerously unpredictable human emotions. The financial projections bloomed, the potential winnings from the Ladies Open turning the spreadsheet’s bottom line a vibrant, beautiful green. The risk of failure, however, now fluctuated wildly with every tiny adjustment she made to Rafael’s volatility. The project was no longer a simple equation to be solved, but a living, breathing system she had to manage. She had traded the tedium of a dying star for the chaos of a forming galaxy. For the first time in a long time, the numbers on the screen felt thrillingly, terrifyingly alive.

The next morning, at 5:58 AM, Rafael was waiting by the first tee box. He wore the clean uniform, his hair was combed, and the sullen defiance of the previous day had been replaced by a tense, watchful neutrality. He had accepted the terms. Isadora arrived at precisely 6:00 AM, carrying not her golf bag, but a portable whiteboard and a briefcase. She did not greet him.
“Phase two begins with a systemic integration,” she announced, setting up the whiteboard on a small easel she produced from her car. “Your intuitive inputs are a raw, unprocessed resource. They need to be refined, standardized, and integrated with my mechanical outputs for maximum efficiency.” She uncapped a marker and drew a complex diagram of a golf swing, broken down into angles, force vectors, and kinetic chains.
“This is my swing plane,” she said, pointing to a series of arcs and lines. “It has a standard deviation of 0.8 degrees on a full iron shot. Your advice to take a ‘soft six’ is imprecise. We need to quantify ‘soft.’ Is that a 90% power swing? An 85%? We need a common language.”

Rafael stared at the whiteboard, at the incomprehensible geometric gibberish, and felt a familiar wave of frustration and boredom wash over him. This was school. This was exactly the kind of rigid, soul-deadening structure he had spent his entire life running away from. “I don’t know,” he said, his voice flat. “It’s the swing you need for the shot. I’ll know it when I see it.”

“Unacceptable,” Isadora countered immediately. “'Knowing it when you see it' is not a scalable strategy. We will drill. You will call a shot, and I will execute it. For a long moment, she just looked at him, her internal processors clearly struggling with an instruction that had no discernible objective. A walk, for her, was a method of transit from Point A to Point B. A walk with no destination was a paradox, a waste of kinetic energy. He ambled with the easy, rolling gait of someone who belonged there, while she strode with her usual brisk, purposeful pace, as if she were late for a meeting. After fifty yards, he stopped. “You’re doing it wrong,” he said. Close your eyes.” She hesitated again, the command to voluntarily disable her primary sensory input a direct violation of her every instinct. But she complied, her eyelids closing with a rigid finality. “Now what?” she asked, her voice tight. “What do you hear?” “I hear an olive-backed sunbird, approximately forty meters to the east,” she recited instantly. “And the mechanical hum of the irrigation system on the eighteenth green. It was an excruciating exercise, like trying to hold back a tidal wave with a picket fence. Her brain wanted to label, to categorize, to file. But she forced it into submission. She pushed past the birdsong and the hum of machinery. She listened. And slowly, she began to hear it. A low, almost sub-audible whisper. The sound of the mist condensing on millions of blades of grass. The gentle sigh of the vast, sleeping course breathing in the morning air. It was a sound she had never heard before, a data point that had never registered. “I hear,” she said slowly, her eyes still closed, “the silence.”

Rafael nodded, though she couldn’t see him. It was a start. They continued like this for over an hour, a series of strange, meditative exercises. He made her kneel and feel the grain of the grass on a green, to feel which way it wanted to bend. They ended up on the twelfth green, a notoriously difficult, three-tiered monster of a putting surface. “Read it,” Rafael said.
